snippet: From Utah through the upper Midwest and into the Northeast, children across much of the North are less likely to live in single-family households on average.
abstract: The Upshot; geographic analysis of census data shows it is more likely that a child will grow up in two-parent household in northern part of the United States than it is in South; also shows that reality differs from conventional wisdom about families in politically conservative and politically liberal states, in part because divorce rates are no longer main reason why children grow up in single-parent households.
lead_paragraph: From Utah through the upper Midwest and into the Northeast, children across much of the North are less likely to live in single-family households on average.

headline.print_headline: A Geographic Divide on Family Life in America
headline.main: The North-South Divide on Two-Parent Families
